fields.title: The Great Gatsby
fields.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
fields.description: A classic novel exploring the American Dream and the excesses of the Jazz Age through the mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby and his obsession with Daisy Buchanan.

fields.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
fields.author: Harper Lee
fields.description: A powerful story of racial injustice and childhood innocence, seen through the eyes of young Scout Finch in the racially segregated American South.

fields.author: George Orwell
fields.description: A dystopian tale of totalitarianism and surveillance, depicting a world where individuality is suppressed and truth is controlled by the Party.

fields.title: The Catcher in the Rye
fields.author: J.D. Salinger
fields.description: An iconic novel about teenage rebellion and alienation, following the experiences of the disillusioned Holden Caulfield in 1950s New York.

fields.title: Pride and Prejudice
fields.author: Jane Austen
fields.description: A beloved romantic comedy that critiques the British class system, focusing on the witty and headstrong Elizabeth Bennet and her complex relationship with Mr. Darcy.

fields.title: The Hobbit
fields.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
fields.description: A fantasy adventure where Bilbo Baggins, a hobbit, embarks on a journey to help a group of dwarves reclaim their homeland from the dragon Smaug.

fields.title: Moby Dick
fields.author: Herman Melville
fields.description: An epic tale of obsession and vengeance, as Captain Ahab relentlessly pursues the great white whale Moby Dick across the seas.

fields.title: War and Peace
fields.author: Leo Tolstoy
fields.description: A grand historical novel set during the Napoleonic Wars, exploring the lives of Russian aristocrats and the impact of war on society.

fields.title: The Odyssey
fields.author: Homer
fields.description: An ancient Greek epic that chronicles the hero Odysseus's perilous journey home after the Trojan War, encountering mythical creatures and divine challenges.

fields.title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer Stone
fields.author: J.K. Rowling
fields.description: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone is a 1997 novel by J. K. Rowling, known elsewhere as Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone1. The story follows young wizard Harry Potter as he solves a mystery involving a sorcerer’s stone, leading him to the evil Voldemort. Filled with imaginative details, this fantasy novel is the first in the immensely popular Harry Potter series

fields.title: The Da Vinci Code
fields.author: Dan Brown
fields.description: A fast-paced thriller that follows symbologist Robert Langdon as he unravels a conspiracy involving the Catholic Church and a secret society.

fields.title: The Alchemist
fields.author: Paulo Coelho
fields.description: A philosophical novel about following one's dreams, telling the story of Santiago, a shepherd who embarks on a journey to find a hidden treasure.

fields.title: The Lord of the Rings
fields.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
fields.description: An epic fantasy saga that follows the quest to destroy a powerful ring and defeat the dark lord Sauron, set in the richly imagined world of Middle-earth.

fields.title: Gone with the Wind
fields.author: Margaret Mitchell
fields.description: A sweeping historical romance set during the American Civil War and Reconstruction, focusing on the life of Scarlett O'Hara and her tumultuous relationships.

fields.title: The Chronicles of Narnia
fields.author: C.S. Lewis
fields.description: A beloved fantasy series that transports readers to the magical land of Narnia, where children become heroes in the battle between good and evil.

fields.title: A Tale of Two Cities
fields.author: Charles Dickens
fields.description: A historical novel set in London and Paris before and during the French Revolution, exploring themes of sacrifice, redemption, and resurrection.

fields.title: The Brothers Karamazov
fields.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
fields.description: A philosophical novel exploring deep ethical and moral questions, centered on the tumultuous lives of the Karamazov family.

fields.title: Brave New World
fields.author: Aldous Huxley
fields.description: A dystopian novel that imagines a future society where humans are engineered and conditioned for specific roles, raising questions about freedom and happiness.

fields.title: Ulysses
fields.author: James Joyce
fields.description: A modernist novel that parallels Homer's Odyssey, following a day in the life of Leopold Bloom in Dublin, using stream-of-consciousness narrative techniques.

fields.title: Crime and Punishment
fields.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
fields.description: A psychological exploration of guilt and redemption, focusing on a young man's moral dilemmas after committing a murder.
